node.title: Is it possible to apply periodic BCs using DGFEM kernels?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello, I am interested in applying the ADDGAdvection kernel, however as I have seen in previous posts when using monomial shape functions the periodic boundary conditions do not currently work. I am wondering if there is any update on this or at least if there is a work around that allows for periodic BCs to be applied to variables using DGKernels.
Currently, my system is a simple Couette shear flow velocity field applied to some conserved variables. I have used ADConservativeAdvection, but there is no full upwinding and the documentation suggests using ADDGAdvection kernels instead.
Would a quick fix be to use the non-AD ConservativeAdvection kernel? But I guess then the conserved variables would have to be Real and I wouldn't be able to couple them with ADReal variables?

@lindsayad on periodic BCs for DG

Would a quick fix be to use the non-AD ConservativeAdvection kernel?

you can absolutely mix AD and non-AD kernels. If that kernel works for you go ahread

But I guess then the conserved variables would have to be Real and I wouldn't be able to couple them with ADReal variables?

There are no AD or non-AD variables. Nonlinear variables can be used by both AD and non-AD kernels

Yea no periodic BCs for DG, but you could use the mortar method instead. You can look in https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/test/tests/mortar/periodic-value for a 2D example and https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/test/tests/mortar/3d-periodic for a 3D example. Those examples use continuous finite element families for the primal variable but that isn't necessary. The only constraint for stability, unless you're using dual shape functions, is that the order of the Lagrange multiplier be one less than for the primal variable, similar to Taylor-Hood elements for velocity-pressure in Navier-Stokes

Thanks for the replies.
I will try mixing the kernels if it comes to it. I tried to implement the mortar method, but I can't seem to get it to work with the DG kernels. At least in terms of the periodic conditions, they seem to work when I use Lagrange elements and the AD advection kernel. Here is that result:

But if I just switch to an  ADDGAdvection kernel and use Monomial elements for some reason the initial condition is not applied to the boundaries and there is strange behavior in the solution.
Here is that result:

Here is my input file built off of the mortar example in case I am making any mistakes:
[Mesh]
  [gmg]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 50
    ny = 50
    xmax = 1
    ymax = 1
  []
  [nb]
    input = gmg
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 1
    bottom_left = '0 0 0'
    top_right = '1 1 0'
    block_name = "domain"
  []
  [secondary]
    input = nb
    type = LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator
    new_block_name = "secondary"
    sidesets = 'right'
  []
  [primary]
    input = secondary
    type = LowerDBlockFromSidesetGenerator
    new_block_name = "primary"
    sidesets = 'left'
  []
[]

[Variables]

  [X_SiO2]
    order = FIRST
    family = MONOMIAL
    block = 'domain'
  []

  [lm]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    block = 'secondary'
  []
[]

[Kernels]

  [time_X_SiO2]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = X_SiO2
    block = 'domain'
  []

  # [advect_X_SiO2]
  #   type = ADConservativeAdvection
  #   variable = X_SiO2
  #   velocity = 'velocity'
  #   block = 'domain'
  # []
[]

[DGKernels]
  [X_SiO2_advect]
    type = ADDGAdvection
    variable = X_SiO2
    velocity = 'velocity'
    block = 'domain'
  []
[]

[ICs]
  [vein_SiO2]
    type = BoundingBoxIC
    variable = X_SiO2
    x1 = 0.45
    x2 = 0.55
    y1 = 0.0
    y2 = 1.0
    inside = 0.36
    outside = 0.45
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [bottom_X_SiO2]
    type = ADConservativeAdvectionBC
    boundary = 'bottom'
    primal_dirichlet_value = 0
    variable = X_SiO2
    velocity_mat_prop = 'velocity'
  []
  [top_X_SiO2]
    type = ADConservativeAdvectionBC
    boundary = 'top'
    primal_dirichlet_value = 0
    variable = X_SiO2
    velocity_mat_prop = 'velocity'
  []
[]

[Constraints]
  [ev]
    type = EqualValueConstraint
    variable = lm
    secondary_variable = X_SiO2
    primary_boundary = 'left'
    secondary_boundary = 'right'
    primary_subdomain = primary
    secondary_subdomain = secondary
    periodic = true
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [vel]
    type = ADVectorFromComponentVariablesMaterial
    vector_prop_name = 'velocity'
    u = 0.1
    v = 0.0
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  num_steps = 25
  dt = 0.005
  solve_type = NEWTON
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

At least in terms of the periodic conditions, they seem to work when I use Lagrange elements and the AD advection kernel. Here is that result:

That result does not look great.  Can you turn on upwinding in the ConservativeAdvection?
It is implemented in that one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/ConservativeAdvection.html

But if I just switch to an ADDGAdvection kernel and use Monomial elements for some reason the initial condition is not applied to the boundaries and there is strange behavior in the solution.

yeah this isnt good. If you look at examples of ADDGAdvection, see this page
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/dgkernels/ADDGAdvection.html
they all also include a ADConservativeAdvection.
The DGKernel works on the internal sidesets only, you need a kernel to compute the integral of the advective term in the weak form over the volume

Hi, I applied full upwinding using ConservativeAdvection, but the solution seems significantly worse than without.
Here is that result after 25 time steps:

I also then tried including ADConservativeAdvection with ADDGAdvection, and the result is much better. Also, it seems to have periodic behavior at the left and right boundaries as desired, but the boundaries still seem to have 0 initial condition that stays constant.
Here is that result over 1000 timesteps:

It seems the DGKernel combined with the mortar method produces the best result so far, but I am unsure how to handle the boundary values, though they don't seem to affect the solution from what I see. But I worry if once I couple the variable to other kernels it may start causing issues.

what you are seeing on the boundary is a visualization artefact because the nodal variables are not block restricted in their output, and the value of the nodal variable is 0 on the primary / secondary subdomains
I see that makes sense. Thanks for the clarification, I'll mark the thread as solved!

node.title: Coupling Navier–Stokes (in tunnel) and Darcy Flow (in porous media) in a single MOOSE simulation?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Navier Stokes is the most appropriate category for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Question
Hi guys,
I’m working on a radon transport problem in which I have two adjacent subdomains:
Subdomain 1 (Tunnel): An open tunnel with incompressible air flow, where I want to use the Navier–Stokes equations.
Subdomain 2 (Porous Media): Surrounding rock or soil, where I want to use Darcy flow (e.g., via the PorousFlow module).
The main objective is to solve for the velocity and pressure fields in both subdomains and track radon concentration across the entire domain, including exchange at the interface.
I have two questions:



Is it possible (or advisable) to solve both the Navier–Stokes and Darcy flow equations in one MOOSE input file (i.e., in a single coupled system)? ie assign block in kernels? also this is a finite volume problem, right?



Are there any existing examples or test input files in MOOSE that demonstrate a setup where one subdomain is governed by Navier–Stokes and another by Darcy flow? I want to see how people typically handle boundary conditions, coupling at the interface, and the combined solve.
Any advice or pointers would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks guys
Traiwit
Additional information
Mesh size and type: 50k to 1mil element
Reynolds number:
Discretization (finite element CG/DG, finite volume, etc): finite volume (maybe)
Models (turbulence, porous media, etc): turbulence & porous media
Solver method (fully coupled, segregated, multiapps, etc): fully coupled
Base input you started from: N/A

Is it possible (or advisable) to solve both the Navier–Stokes and Darcy flow equations in one MOOSE input file (i.e., in a single coupled system)? ie assign block in kernels? also this is a finite volume problem, right?

possible certainly. You can assign blocks to variables to limit their domain of definition. Advisable you'll see but it's very easy to pivot from fully-coupled to multi-system fixed-point (or multiapp)

also this is a finite volume problem, right?

our best solver for navier stokes is a custom linear finite volume discretization. It can scale to Ms of elements. You can still use the finite element or regular nonlinear finite volume solvers, but they wont go much beyond 100k elements

Are there any existing examples or test input files in MOOSE that demonstrate a setup where one subdomain is governed by Navier–Stokes and another by Darcy flow?

not that I know.
What are your variables for Darcy flow? only pressure right? You should be able to use boundary conditions to make two pressure connect on the boundary

Hi @GiudGiud, thanks for the prompt reply!
I still try to get my head around the kernels and variables for each system (lets call them tunnel and porous media)
lets say we use finite volume for the whole system for simplicity.
In the tunnel, I'd want to solve Navier stokes, we use all the Navier stokes kernels there - to solve velocity field and P
and then in the porous media, I use the kernel from porous flow (Darcy flow)? but this will only solve P and velocity field will be its by-product
are these P and velocity field from both kernel systems the same?
Also, do they share fluid property system? (I kinda want to use single fluid system - simple Air)
then I use FVAdvection and FVDiffusion for both tunnel and porous media for Radon tracking (right?, or there are special Advection-Diffusion for NS system)
as you can see, i'm quite confused, I just want to simplify the system and number of variables I need to solve before I actually start
Thanks!
Traiwit

are these P and velocity field from both kernel systems the same?

it wont be easy with finite volume to make them the same. For NSFV, you need to use an INSFVPressureVariable for example.

Also, do they share fluid property system? (I kinda want to use single fluid system - simple Air)

yes they can use the same properties

then I use FVAdvection and FVDiffusion for both tunnel and porous media

So radon is passive scalar being advected?
You cannot use FVAdvection with NS because the face interpolation scheme would be inconsistent for velocities (rhie chow in NSFV, average or upwind in FVAdvection). You need to use INSFVScalarAdvection
For porous media I think it should be fine to use FVAdvection but I dont know.
FVDiffusion fine I for NS. I dont know about porous media

@Traiwit we did integrate NS modules, though against PF module but a in house developed moose app. This said, it should work as smooth as in our case for PF module. You just need to careful in deciding what to exchange between the two domains.
Here is a reference of a recent publication (https://doi.org/10.1029/2024JB029001). Maybe it can help

Hi @mcacace, wow very complicated framework esp with Mechanical simulation on top of it!
so you'd suggest to break them into 2 systems (in your case 3) and exchange the data between them (via BC or IC for the next step?)
just wondering, did you feed pressure field from NS back into PF and vice-versa? (I should have carefully read the paper before asking)
great work btw!
Traiwit

@Traiwit

so you'd suggest to break them into 2 systems (in your case 3) and exchange the data between them (via BC or IC for the next step?)

We relied on a multiapp set up because of the very different scales. We required a 3 system only for some specific internal reasons, but in your case 2 would be enough.

Just wondering, did you feed pressure field from NS back into PF and vice-versa? (I should have carefully read the paper before asking)

We did pass exchange pressure, velocity and other quantity of interest from one system to the other when needed in terms of BC conditions (need to write some custom BC, but no big issue). It should be all explained in the paper, but in case I can provide you some more details.
mauro
BTW, our porous HM simulations are not based on the PF module neither the solid mechanics, but as said, it should be relatively straightforward to make use of existing modules

Hi guys, update, i'm still trying to push through solving both in 1 system
please see the input file below (there are a few problems that i might need help @GiudGiud i'm not sure who is the expert in NS module)

I come across https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/navier_stokes/pinsfv.html which seems to be what i want
when i tried to implement [Physics/NavierStokes] [ScalarTransport] with it i got this error
Porous media scalar advection is currently unimplemented
which reasonable since NS is quite new in MOOSE (though I'd also like to know the timeline of this implementation :) )
just wondering is there a way to work around this?
since pinsfv only generate SuperficialVelocity is there a way to convert it to normal INSFVVelocityVariable? then I can do advection-diffusion via kernels
or is there a way to separate them by subdomain? ie only let porous_medium_treatment = true in block 2 and only track concentration in block 1, but in this case i still need to make sure that pressure and vel between 2 subdomains are talking to each other (which I still dont know how)
Any advice would be greatly appreciated! i'm super new to this MOOSE-NS thing
Traiwit
# Fluid properties
mu = 1.1
rho = 1.1
cp = 1.1
k = 1e-3

# Operating conditions
u_inlet = 1
T_inlet = 15
T_solid = 25
p_outlet = 10
h_fs = 0.01

[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 20
    ymin = -2
    ymax = 2
    zmin = -2
    zmax = 2
    nx = 20
    ny = 5
    nz = 10
    elem_type = TET
  []

  [bottom]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = gen
    location = inside
    bottom_left = '10 -2 -2'
    top_right = '20 2 2'
    block_id = 1
  []
[]


[Physics]
  [NavierStokes]
    [Flow]
      [flow]
        compressibility = 'incompressible'
        
        porous_medium_treatment = true
        porosity = porosity

        density = 'rho'
        dynamic_viscosity = 'mu'

        initial_velocity = '${u_inlet} 0 0'
        initial_pressure = 0.0

        inlet_boundaries = 'left'
        momentum_inlet_types = 'fixed-velocity'
        momentum_inlet_function = '${u_inlet} 0 0'
        wall_boundaries = 'bottom top front back'
        momentum_wall_types = 'noslip noslip noslip noslip'

        outlet_boundaries = 'right'
        momentum_outlet_types = 'fixed-pressure-zero-gradient'
        pressure_function = '${p_outlet}'

        mass_advection_interpolation = 'average'
        momentum_advection_interpolation = 'average'
      []
    []

  []
[]

[Physics/NavierStokes]
  [FluidHeatTransfer]
    [heat]
      coupled_turbulence_physics = 'turbulence'
      thermal_conductivity = 'k'
      specific_heat = 'cp'

      fluid_temperature_variable = 'T_fluid'
      initial_temperature = 30 # '${T_inlet}'
      energy_inlet_types = 'heatflux'
      energy_inlet_functors = '${fparse u_inlet * rho * cp * T_inlet}'

      energy_wall_types = 'heatflux heatflux heatflux heatflux'
      energy_wall_functors = '0 0 0 0'

      ambient_convection_alpha = 'h_cv'
      ambient_temperature = 'T_solid'

      energy_advection_interpolation = 'average'
    []
  []
[]

# [Physics/NavierStokes]
#   [ScalarTransport]
#     [Radon]
#       coupled_turbulence_physics = 'turbulence'
#       passive_scalar_names = 'scalar'
#       coupled_flow_physics = 'flow'
#       fluid_heat_transfer_physics = 'heat'

#       passive_scalar_diffusivity = 0.2
#       passive_scalar_source = 0.5

#       passive_scalar_inlet_types = 'fixed-value'
#       passive_scalar_inlet_function = '0'

#       passive_scalar_advection_interpolation = 'average'
#     []
#   []
# []

[Physics/NavierStokes]
[Turbulence]
  [turbulence]
    coupled_flow_physics = flow
    fluid_heat_transfer_physics = heat
  []
[]
[]

[FunctorMaterials]
  [constants]
    type = ADGenericFunctorMaterial
    prop_names = 'h_cv T_solid rho mu cp k'
    prop_values = '${h_fs} ${T_solid} ${rho} ${mu} ${cp} ${k}'
  []

  [constants2]
    type = ADGenericFunctorMaterial
    prop_names = 'porosity'
    prop_values = porosity_fx
  []
[]

[Functions]
    [./porosity_fx]
      type = ParsedFunction
      expression = if(x>=10,0.1,1)
    [../]
  []

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'

  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -pc_type -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_levels'
  petsc_options_value = '300                bjacobi  ilu          4'
  line_search = 'none'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  dt = 0.2
  end_time = 30
  automatic_scaling = true
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

I am a developer for the NS module I can help

just wondering is there a way to work around this?

the easy way here is to add epsilon in the kernels for the scalar advection. It should be fairly reasonable.
I almost did back then but was not sure where epsilon (the porosity) came in for some terms so I abstained.

or is there a way to separate them by subdomain? ie only let porous_medium_treatment = true in block 2 and only track concentration in block 1, but in this case i still need to make sure that pressure and vel between 2 subdomains are talking to each other (which I still dont know how)

You can define two physics with different porous media settings  and different variables and use interface kernels to make the connection manually. It wont solve the porous media scalar advection problem ?

the easy way here is to add epsilon in the kernels for the scalar advection. It should be fairly reasonable.
I almost did back then but was not sure where epsilon came in for some terms so I abstained.

I'm not exactly sure what it is and where it is, but thank you for pointing this out @GiudGiud! i'll look into this tomorrow!
if there is an easy fix like by-passing some of the required parameters would be nice, i dont need it to be super realistic at its current stage

It wont solve the porous media scalar advection problem

That's true, I thought i'd need to track concentration only in the tunnel, but it has to also come from porous media area (stupid me)
Traiwit

haha it could be that simple
I ll talk with porous media people to be sure

node.title: Reference Papers - Phase Field Equations
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I would appreciate if i can get the paper that is used for developing phase field equations in MOOSE phase field.
Thanks,
Yohan

Hello
Probably one of these
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/phase_field/doc/content/bib/phase_field.bib
but @dschwen @laagesen will know

Yes this is a good list. There is not one single paper that encompasses all the models available, so the list that @GiudGiud shared is a good start. If there is a specific model or kernels that you have questions on, we can probably point you to a more specific paper.

node.title: Compilation fails on macOS: Missing pyyaml dependency and clang -fopenmp error
node.bodyText:
When I followed the steps below to install MOOSE, I encountered some issues.
conda init --all
conda update --all --yes
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.12.23=mpich
conda activate moose
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose
cd test 
make -j6
~/software/moose/test (next) » make clean && make -j6                                                            jltu@jldeMacBook-Pro
WARNING: Failed to initialize PreMake for version checking; this may be ignored but may suggest an environment issue.

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/../scripts/premake.py", line 20, in __init__
    from versioner import Versioner
  File "/Users/jltu/software/moose/scripts/versioner.py", line 24, in <module>
    import yaml
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'yaml'

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/../scripts/premake.py", line 261, in <module>
    PreMake().check()
    ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/../scripts/premake.py", line 27, in __init__
    self.versioner_meta = Versioner().version_meta()
                          ^^^^^^^^^
UnboundLocalError: cannot access local variable 'Versioner' where it is not associated with a value
make: [prebuild] Error 1 (ignored)
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/build/unity_src/linesearches_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/build/unity_src/mesh_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/build/unity_src/fvics_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/build/unity_src/auxkernels_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/build/unity_src/kernels_Unity.C...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/jltu/software/moose/framework/build/unity_src/executioners_Unity.C...

make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
clang: error: unsupported option '-fopenmp'

clang: error: unsupported option '-fopenmp'

(moose) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
~/software/moose/test (next) » echo -e '#include <omp.h>\n#include <stdio.h>\nint main() { \n#pragma omp parallel\n printf("Thread %d\\n", omp_get_thread_num()); \n}' > test_omp.c
(moose) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
~/software/moose/test (next*) » $CC -fopenmp test_omp.c -o test_omp                                              jltu@jldeMacBook-Pro
ld: warning: dylib (/opt/homebrew/Cellar/llvm/19.1.0/lib/libomp.dylib) was built for newer macOS version (12.7) than being linked (12.0)
ld: warning: dylib (/opt/homebrew/Cellar/llvm/19.1.0/lib/libunwind.dylib) was built for newer macOS version (12.7) than being linked (12.0)
ld: warning: dylib (/opt/homebrew/Cellar/llvm/19.1.0/lib/libunwind.dylib) was built for newer macOS version (12.7) than being linked (12.0)
(moose) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
~/software/moose/test (next*) » ./test_omp                                                                       jltu@jldeMacBook-Pro
Thread 0
Thread 6
Thread 4
Thread 1
Thread 2
Thread 5
Thread 7
Thread 3
Was this a Homebrew issue? I'd like to turn this into a Discussion so it may be discovered by others as a possible sollution.

This isn't the first time I've installed moose on this Mac. Previous installations went smoothly. Although I don't know the source of this error, after struggling with it for a long time, I deleted a bunch of environment variables set in the .zshrc file, completely removed conda and related components, restarted my Mac, and finally succeeded in installing it by following the official moose website's instructions.

node.title: SolutionIC
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Dear all, this is more a comment than a real issue...
I have been using the SolutionIC to set up the initial condition from an existing exodus. What I noticed is that if we integrate it in a [ICs] object all works properly, but if integrated in a [InitialCondition] object it returns all zeros --> it seems that the userobject is either called after the [Variables] and inherited [InitialCondition] definition or its information is retrieve after. Not sure if this is on purpose, but if yes, might be worth to throw a warning?
mauro

hello
I ll take a look, this is indeed an issue
Excellent @GiudGiud!

I cant reproduce the behavior with a modified solution_ic.i test

[Variables]
  [u]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    [InitialCondition]
      type = SolutionIC
      solution_uo = exo_soln
      variable = u
      from_variable = 'u'
      block = 0
    []
  []
  [u_elem]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [InitialCondition]
      type = SolutionIC
      solution_uo = exo_soln
      variable = u_elem
      from_variable = 'u_elem'
    []
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [u_aux]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE

    [InitialCondition]
      type = SolutionIC
      solution_uo = exo_soln
      variable = u_aux
      from_variable = 'u_aux'
    []
  []
  [u_aux_elem]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL

    [InitialCondition]
      type = SolutionIC
      solution_uo = exo_soln
      variable = u_aux_elem
      from_variable = 'u_aux_elem'
    []
  []
[]

can you please share with me a reproducible example? with either MOOSE, a module or an open-source app if needed

@GiudGiud somehow I cannot reproduce it any longer. I'd suggest I close it, and if I should encounter this behavior again will share it with you. Sorry about that!
Mauro
sounds good thanks for double checking

node.title: Automatic reply with "most relevant posts"

node.bodyText: Are you using word2vec?
I'm thinking of doc2vec from gensim. But ya, basically the same thing.
I found this github bot (https://github.com/dhrubasaha08/Discuss-Bot). We have open-source LLM on INL HPC and a rag pipeline ready. I would love to try this out and see how it works

node.title: Short courses on GPU constitutive modeling
node.bodyText:
Hello folks,
I want to bring to your attention two upcoming training opportunities on NEML2:

The MOOSE International Workshop, March 13th: https://inl.gov/mooseworkshop2025/
USNCCM 18, July 12th: https://usnccm18.usacm.org/short-courses

NEML2 is a GPU constitutive modeling library. See its online documentation here.
NEML2 can be used together with MOOSE. See related MOOSE documentation here.
Thank you,
Gary

node.title: Grain size distribution output
node.bodyText: Is there a way (e.g., AuxVariable, PostpProcessor, etc.) to make the PhaseField module output at each timestep the grain size distrbution in, e.g., a 2D simulation of grain growth? Can I manipulate GrainTracker or BndsCalcAux to do such a thing? To be more specific, how to edit the grain_growth_2D_graintracker.i example to add this capability?

Hello
so you want a histogram of the grain size distribution?

This one will give you the average. It could be reworked into a vectorpostprocessor to give the distribution as a histogram
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/AverageGrainVolume.html

node.title: Cannot install moose by conda, conda_forge::_libgcc_mutex does not exist.
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
Hello, I am trying to install moose by conda. Firstly I tried to install it on my local windows machine. I installed miniconda3 on the WSL and create an new environment for moose. The I add the channel by
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
and install moose by conda install moose. But I got the following errors:

I searched the _libgcc_mutex, there is a packed named anaconda::_libgcc_mutex, but there is no conda_forge::_libgcc_mutex.
Then I tried to install moose by conda on a remote linux server, it also failed.

(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

hello
delete your moose conda environment
then update conda
then try again with a fresh moose conda environment
the dependencies of an old moose conda package are not resolvable at this point

Thanks for your reply.
Unfortunately, it does not work. I have updated the conda to 25.1.1. And I find that there is a package named conda-forge::_libgcc_mutex, there is no such a conda channel called conda_forge. Maybe there is a spelling mistake in the moose package ?
what OS are you using? What does the diagnostics script in moose/scripts return?
I am using windows and trying to install moose in WSL. I also tried it on linux (CentOS 7) and I get the same error.

These operating systems are too old to be using the Conda-Forge channel. And our packages require packages from the Conda-Forge channel. So there will never another solution other than to use a modern Linux OS.
My advice is to use Rocky-8 or higher, or Ubuntu 24.x or higher. Being that these are WSL images, it relatively easy to switch back and forth. I think I read that you also tried Ubuntu? Can you switch back to that one and report what a diagnostic run says:
cd ~/projects/moose/scripts
./diagnostics.sh
Thanks, I'll try it. I also want to ask another question. Can I install the latest gcc and mpich in a conda environment and then follow the instructions in gcc_install_moose to build moose ?

node.title: Changing the solution value
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello,
I wanted to see if it is possible to change the solution value in the MOOSE framework for a nonlinear variable.
For example, I want to solve Laplace equation to solve for \phi. Then I want to set the \phi variable to 0 when c > 0. Here c is the order parameter in phase field and it is a coupled variable. both \phi and c are nonlinear variables
Any guidance on this is highly appreciated.
Best,
Ali

Hello
You can do this two ways (at least)
First you can enforce this constraint when solving the nonlinear system using the Bounds
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Bounds/index.html
Then you dont need to change the value after the solve
Or you can use a Corrector object (you ll have to code a new one, I dont think we have any that applies a bound, if we dont, happy to see a contribution to moose on this) to act after the solution has been found by the nonlinear system

No, I do not want to set any bound on my variable. I just want to zero them out on certain parts of the computational domain where c>0. Please see the attached.

Thanks,
Corrector should do then
